sub_title: Project Manager, Translational Research & Precision Medicine @ Genmab
summary:
I am a forward-thinking life scientist, with over five years of international experience in preclinical studies, science communication, and project coordination in multiple areas of scientific research, from working both in academia and in biotech/biopharma companies. 

I am also devoted to cultivating long-term stakeholder relationships and bringing valuable ideas to life for the betterment of society.

awards.title: Travel Grant - "The future of oncology"
awards.description:
Course: “The future of oncology: from major challenges of fundamental to translational cancer research”. The Paris Alliance for Cancer Research Institutes (PACRI). Host institution: Institut Curie, Paris - France. March 23-24, 2017. 

Description: This course gathered 20 renowned speakers who addressed the key topics and the major challenges of fundamental and translational cancer research in the next years.

https://enseignement.curie.fr/en/futureofoncology

awards.title: Trainee Grant - "Introduction to Mathematical and Computational Modelling"​
awards.description:
“Introduction to Mathematical and Computational Modelling: from mouse to computer and back”. Host institution: Eindhoven University of Technology, The Netherlands. Period: 17/01/2017 to 19/01/2017.

Description: The training school provided an introduction to mathematical and computational modelling for scientists that work with animal models of disease.
 

http://www.mouseage.eu/events/introduction-mathematical-and-computational-modelling-mouse-computer-and-back

awards.title: Trainee Grant for SynaNet workshop on Neuroinflammation
awards.description: This workshop focused on current research in neuroinflammation and its interrelationship with neurological disorders and synapse function.

profile_positions.title: Project Manager, Research Program Management

profile_positions.description:
Thesis title: "The fate of drugs in the body: the impact of drug transporters and metabolizing
enzymes on the pharmacokinetics of opioids and other substrates"

My Ph.D. research focused on understanding how membrane drug transporters (such as P-gp, BCRP, and OATPs) and drug-metabolizing enzymes (like CYP3A4) can have an impact on the plasma exposure and tissue disposition of several compounds.

For that, we made use of wild-type and genetically modified mouse models and cell lines, which are knockout or humanized for the drug transporter/enzyme of interest and have proved to be excellent tools to elucidate factors that affect both the safety and efficacy profiles of drugs.

Ph.D. project supervised by:

Dr. A. H. Schinkel (https://www.nki.nl/divisions/pharmacology/schinkel-a-group/) 
Prof. Dr. J. H. Beijnen (https://www.uu.nl/staff/JHBeijnen/Profile)
profile_positions.title: PHD Graduate Student

profile_positions.description:
- Proved capacity to embrace teamwork, as being part of a multidisciplinary team of four other Ph.D. students from different cultural backgrounds.

- Capable of applying design thinking and impact entrepreneurship training to find an innovative solution so complex patients (such as transplant patients) at the University Medical Center Groningen can feel empowered and have the tools to improve their overall quality of life after hospital discharge. 

- Able to independently identify relevant resources of information, synthesize and cite others' work, prioritize and assign tasks, and effectively collaborate with the other team members.

- Responsible for chairing and presenting (both orally and written) the team's progress in several meetings with multiple stakeholders.

- Proved strong communication and organizational skills by conducting several one-on-one interviews with multiple healthcare professionals and taking minutes.
profile_positions.title: Participant @ Innovating Public Health Program (Aletta Jacobs School of Public Health)

company.name: Federal University of Rio de Janeiro

profile_positions.company: Federal University of Rio de Janeiro
profile_positions.description:
- Proved experience in collaborating with a wide range of professionals from different areas of expertise by working in an entirely new field of knowledge involving the expression of recombinant dengue serotype 1 capsid protein (DENVC1). The research included structural studies using fluorescence spectrometry, to understand why DENVC1 and DENVC2 present different transfection activities. 

Website: http://www.bioqmed.ufrj.br/docentes/?u=dapoian - Laboratório de Bioquímica de Vírus, Instituto de Bioquímica Médica Leopoldo de Meis, Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
profile_positions.title: Visiting Graduate Researcher

company.name: Urânia Agência de Conteúdo (Science Communication Company)

profile_positions.company: Urânia Agência de Conteúdo (Science Communication Company)
profile_positions.description:
- Exhibited a high capacity to share scientific knowledge with the general public by working as a content producer for the website of the magazine "Ciência Hoje" and its social media.

- Proved ability to work as a team and to meet the challenges of new activities with quality and punctuality.

Website: http://www.cienciahoje.org.br/ 

About the company:
Urânia is a young Brazilian company with the great challenge of making scientific knowledge available to the largest number of people. The heart of the company is the expertise of its journalists, which have vast experience in science communication.
Urânia works to create content for magazines, books, museums and websites, with the purpose of help researchers or research centers in the dissemination of their studies’ results and the development of scientific popularization projects.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Graduate Reseacher

profile_positions.description:
- In collaboration with TechnoPhage (Portuguese biopharmaceutical company), and by using a technology that SpliceBio (former name: ProteoDesign) had developed, helped to modify their novel recombinant single-domain antibody (sdAb) fragment against the amyloid-beta peptide in Alzheimer’s disease, by adding a fluorescent molecule. This new product proved to be effective thus confirming it was a viable strategy to modify the TechnoPhage’s sdAb. 


website: https://splice.bio/
profile_positions.title: Visiting Graduate Researcher

profile_positions.location: Santa Cruz De Tenerife e Região, Espanha
profile_positions.description:
- Helped to set up an in-house Irwin Test (an in vivo behavioural and physiological toxicity assay) in mice. Used it to evaluate and prioritise new lead anti-cancer compounds.

- Learned and performed orthotopic xenograft studies in immunosuppressed nude mice using human breast cancer cells.

- Performed cell viability (MTT assay) and cell growth (SRB assay) assays using several different types of human cancer cells, to help evaluate and prioritise new anti-cancer compounds.

- Successfully performed cell culture, cryopreservation and contributed to ensure the integrity of all cell lines used by the company.


Website: http://www.ceamedsa.com/?lan=EN
profile_positions.title: Visiting Graduate Researcher

profile_positions.location: Baía de São Francisco e Região, Estados Unidos
profile_positions.description:
- Coordinated a team in order to implement an Alzheimer’s disease rat model. This allowed the study of the effect of amyloid beta-protein at a molecular level and in behaviour in rodents. 

- Collaborated on another project of the lab that involved the monitoring of tau protein toxicity in cardiomyocytes by using MTT assay. 

- Evaluated the neuroprotective action of Kyotorphin using primary neuronal cultures and immunocytochemistry. 

- Trained two researchers on different in vivo techniques using rats; techniques including stereotaxic brain surgery, transcardial perfusion and behavioural tests, demonstrating outstanding time management and interpersonal skills. 

Website: http://bioadd.stanford.edu/
profile_positions.title: Visiting Graduate Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Curricular Internship – Master’s Degree in Neuroscience | Final Mark: 20 (mark scale: 0-20) 

Supervisors: Prof. Ana Sebastião & Prof. Miguel Castanho, FMUL

Title: “Neuroprotective action of a Kyotorphin (KTP) derivative in an animal model of Alzheimer’s disease.”

- Implemented, for the first time at iMM,  a non-transgenic rat model of Alzheimer’s disease, with ethical approval from all competent Portuguese authorities.  

- Created a new research line, resulting in a PhD thesis for a peer, and the animal model implemented is now being used for other students in the lab.

- Identified a novel neuroprotective action of a Kyotorphin derivative in an animal model of Alzheimer’s Disease by executing several techniques, including immunohistochemistry and western blotting and by using several in vivo protocols, such as brain surgery, behavioural tests (Y-Maze, Novel Object Recognition, Open Field), animal dosing, transcardial perfusion, tissue collection and hippocampus dissection, which resulted in a submitted publication as co-author.

- Independently planned and wrote the entire research plan, leading to a final grade of 20/20 for Master’s thesis defence showing outstanding research work (only student with the maximum grade).

- Independently supervised one undergraduate student demonstrating good project management skills and excellent ability to work as part of a collaborative team.

- Proved excellent communication and presentation skills by giving several oral and poster presentations at different scientific meetings.
profile_positions.title: Master Thesis Student

profile_positions.description:
Curricular Internship – Bachelor’s Degree in Human Biology | Final Mark: 20 (mark scale: 0-20) 

Supervisors: Luísa Romão, PhD & Alexandre Teixeira, PhD (INSA)

Title: “Suppression of nonsense mutations as a therapeutic approach to treat beta-thalassemia.” 

- Successfully performed several and different molecular biology methods, ranging from classic cloning techniques, to automated DNA sequencing, to in vitro transcription.
profile_positions.title: Bachelor Student

volunteer_experiences.description:
Proactive team player and excellent communication skills shown by volunteer work with the Palo Alto community “Magic”. The work included: collecting food from farmers’ market and give it to a food bank and watering California oaks on Stanford University open space land.
This unforgettable experience provided the learning and development of important social skills, how to do valuable work with a team, how to manage time in order to be available to participate in these activities, be more conscious of environmental causes, and helped with the acquisition of new insights, especially from meeting a diverse range of people with different ways of looking at the World.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic,_Inc._(organization)
